bioghist.p: The Free Library of Philadelphia was founded in 1891 as the city's first public library system. Its Rare Book Department, among the largest in American public libraries, exists to serve the people of Philadelphia, as well as the students, scholars, and researchers who use its collections. The Rare Book Department's holding span 5000 years, from cuneiform tablets to 20th century literary manuscripts. Among the many collecting areas of the department are incunabula, American, European, and Oriental manuscripts, art and artist's papers, children's books and manuscripts, manuscripts and correspondence of American and British authors, examples of calligraphy, and Pennsylvania German fraktur. The Rare Book Department has major collections of Oliver Goldsmith, Charles Dickens, Edgar Allan Poe, Horace editions, Beatrix Potter, Arthur Rackham, and Robert Lawson.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains an extensive assortment of books on writing and penmanship, received from Columbia Teacherâ€™s College. Volumes include sample alphabets, penmanship guides for school and business use, exercise books, and books on other topics showing examples of calligraphy. There are both printed and manuscript volumes. Dates range from 1554 to 1969. The bulk of the volumes are American. Among the American volumes are several series of manuals published by Shaylor, Spencer, Perkins & Fairman, and Payson, Dunton & Scribner. There are also volumes from England, France, Germany, Holland, Italy, Spain, and Japan. The collection also includes several framed and unbound samples of ornate calligraphy, several of which are hand-colored; and a display of signature cards mounted on a velvet-covered board.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
